awd_titl_txt: ABR: Collaborative research: Computational Jewelry for Mobile Health
awd_abstract_narration:
Mobile health (mHealth) technology promises to improve quality of life, improve individual and public health, and reduce healthcare costs. Although mHealth devices and applications are proliferating, challenges remain. With a focus on usability, manageability, interoperability, availability, security, and privacy, the Amulet project has worked to engineer the tools for, and lay the scientific foundation of, secure wearable mHealth by developing a general framework for body-area pervasive computing, centered around health-monitoring and health-management applications. The Amulet team has built a prototype computational jewelry platform: an electronic bracelet and a software framework that enables developers to create (and users to easily use) safe, secure, and efficient mHealth applications that fit seamlessly into everyday life. This accomplishment-based renewal extends this work?refining and extending the Amulet platform?s functionality,  evaluating its performance and usability in larger-scale studies, and transitioning the technology into an open and extensible tool for the research and healthcare communities.

The investigators expect Amulet will be a platform for a wide range of mHealth applications, and this project evaluates this potential in a concrete setting in cooperation with the Center for Technology and Behavioral Health at Dartmouth College. This project explores use of the Amulet platform in new applications, using new wearable sensors and new kinds of user interactions. This exploration includes fielding Amulet prototypes to study stress and other behavioral health metrics, and refining the Amulet hardware and software in response to user feedback, in order to prepare the platform for a successful public release to the research community. The Amulet will open exciting new opportunities as it becomes available to both technology and health-science researchers as they explore the burgeoning field of wearable technology.

por.por_cntn:
The Amulet project sought to develop computational jewelry -- that is, a wearable computing device that is convenient and secure -- in the service of health and wellness. Specifically, the ?Amulet? is an electronic wristband that serves as a secure computational platform, able to run multiple health-related applications while maintaining a secure body-area network of related mobile-health devices for sensing and actuation, and presenting its wearer visual feedback. With a focus on mHealth applications, Amulet emphasizes security, privacy, and long battery life.

With the support of this renewed funding, the Amulet team has improved the Amulet hardware and software, integrated Amulet with additional sensors, and used the Amulet platform to support medical research studies, with an emphasis on monitoring stress and on measuring physical activity among older adults.  As a result of this work, the latest prototype Amulet can more efficiently run multiple applications with secure isolation among applications, while using Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) to communicate with a companion smartphone and wearable sensor devices, several in-built sensors (temperature, ambient UV light, sound, acceleration, and gyroscope), a microSD card for storing data, a display, two LEDs, haptic vibration feedback, two buttons, and a capacitive-touch slider. The team has improved Amulet?s physical design with a smaller more comfortable case, buttons that are easier to use, and more convenient connectors for programming, charging, and debugging software problems. The team has also improved the platform?s battery life and improved the robustness and security of its applications and operating system. Improvements to Amulet?s programming tools allow application developers to not only predict their application's power consumption, but also determine how different events and design decisions contribute to an application's power draw. These improvements include a novel technique for efficiently isolating application memory on processors without traditional memory protection hardware, and a novel cryptographic technique for delivering sensed data to the cloud, where it can be selectively shared. The Amulet prototype hardware and software is freely available for non-commercial use by researchers and others interested in exploring the potential for wearable technology.

In addition to improvements to the Amulet platform, the team has also developed two additional sensors: a wearable EDA (electrodermal activity) sensor that fits snugly into a cheap Fitbit Flex wristband, and a sensor for exercise bands (like those typified by the "Theraband" brand) allowing the Amulet to receive real-time force data from the exercise band.

The team also explored the suitability of smartwatch applications to assist students with Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities, identified privacy concerns and misconceptions that are common with mobile health devices, and developed new ways to predict when an individual is likely to respond to mHealth intervention prompts.

Finally, using these new sensors and working with collaborators, including physician-researchers at Dartmouth?s Geisel School of Medicine, the team also developed and evaluated new monitoring techniques focusing on real-time stress detection and on monitoring the physical-activity levels and abilities of older adults. To measure stress, the Amulet uses internal and external wearable sensors to collect real-time, continuous measurements of the wearer?s physiological indications of stress, and compares those measurements with the wearer?s in-the-moment perception of stress. Another set of applications, ActivityAware and GeriActive, help older adults maintain their strength by monitoring their performance while they perform prescribed exercises. The team has conducted a series of pilot studies in both application areas to understand Amulet?s suitability, with resulting data and models that will enable new Amulet applications and real-time interventions to encourage healthy living.

For more information, including links to publications, source repositories, and video, see amulet-project.org.
